title: Protocol to assess metabolic activity of Pseudomonas aeruginosa by measuring heat flow using isothermal calorimetry
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of growth models: surface attached biofilm (SB), alginate bead embedded cells (AB) and planktonic cultures (PC)
Timing: 2 days
This section describes the preparation of P. aeruginosa growth models for surface attached biofilm, alginate bead embedded cells and planktonic cells. Surface biofilms is incubated directly inside non-activated plastic inserts (calWells™, Symcel AB, Sweden) to allow further metabolic measurements, while alginate beads are incubated in Erlenmeyer flasks and planktonic cultures in cell culture tubes and then transferred to plastic wells upon measurements.
Surface attached biofilm formation has been optimized for the plastic inserts and the planktonic culture preparation has been adapted. The encapsulation of bacteria in alginate beads is done using a modification of previously described protocols.11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11],12[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]
The full workflow is illustrated in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2661-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Workflow of preparing Pseudomonas aeruginosa in different growth models
(A) For planktonic cultures, 5 mL LB is inoculated from −80°C freeze stock and shaken at 180 rpm for 24 h at 37°C. The ON culture is then filtered through a 10 μm syringe filter and adjusted to an OD600 of 0.005 using a spectrophotometer.
(B) For production of alginate beads, a filtered and OD600 adjusted ON culture is mixed with alginate. Following homogenization, alginate beads containing bacteria are produced by extrusion dropping into a stirred CaCl2 solution and beads are hardened for 1 h before being washed and transferred to Erlenmeyer flasks containing LB medium.
(C) For production of surface biofilms, a filtered and OD600 adjusted ON culture is pipetted into individual plastic inserts, positioned in a standard 48 well plate and incubated for 24 h in 37°C and shaken at 120 rpm. Following incubation, media is removed, and the wells washed with sterile saline, and then transferred to titanium vials of the calPlate.

Note: Two of the strains used here have an arabinose-inducible promoter. Thus, 0.2% L-arabinose (final concentration) should be added to induce the promoter. Here, we mixed LB with arabinose for inoculation into the calWells™ just prior to insertion in the calScreener™.
Note: Use plastic inserts of calWells™ for setting up the growth model; that allows a direct measurement of the samples.
Prepare a planktonic culture
Timing: 1 h
Filter the ON culture through a 10 μm syringe filter to ensure a mainly planktonic population.
Measure the OD of the filtered ON culture on a spectrophotometer and adjust to a final OD600 of 0.005 in sterile LB supplemented with 0.2% arabinose.
Add an aliquot of 200 μL to each plastic insert.
Position plastic inserts into titanium vial of the calPlate™ (Symcel AB, Sweden)
Preparation of surface attached biofilm in plastic inserts
Timing: 25 h (preparation ∼1 h; incubation ∼24 h)
Filter the ON culture through a 10 μm syringe filter to ensure a mainly planktonic population.
Measure the OD of the filtered ON culture on a spectrophotometer and adjust to a final OD600 of 0.005 in sterile LB.
Fill the sterile plastic inserts (Symcel AB, Sweden) with 200 μL of the OD-adjusted ON culture.
Cover the plastic inserts with parafilm, position them in a 48-well plate and incubate for 24 h at 37°C, 120 rpm for biofilm to develop on the sides and bottom of the insert.
Following incubation, remove planktonic biomass by removing supernatant gently, then washing gently with 200 μL sterile saline solution (0.9% NaCl).
After washing, position inserts into titanium vials of the calPlate™ (Symcel AB, Sweden).
Add 200 μL fresh LB media supplemented with 0.2% L-arabinose to each plastic insert.
Preparation of P. aeruginosa encapsulated in alginate beads
Timing: 26 h (preparation ∼1.5 h; incubation ∼24 h)

Encapsulation of P. aeruginosa in alginate beads follows the procedure as described elsewhere.11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11],12[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12] In case of problems forming the spheres see troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1].
Filter the ON culture through a 10 μm syringe filter to ensure a mainly planktonic population.
Measure the OD of the filtered ON culture on a spectrophotometer and adjust to an OD600 of 2.
Dilute the OD adjusted culture 20× in a sterile alginate solution (2% w/v) to a final OD600 of 0.1.
Place 150 mL of sterile 0.25 M CaCl2 in a 250 mL beaker glass on a magnetic stirrer with a sterile magnet (∼3 cm length).
Set the magnetic stirrer to 150 rpm and place a 21-gauge needle perpendicular to- and ∼3 cm from the surface of the CaCl2 solution, and ∼1.5 cm from the edge of the beaker.
Connect the needle to a 20 mL syringe containing the alginate-bacterial solution by sterile silicone tubing (internal diameter = 2 mm).
Mount the syringe into a syringe pump and set the flow rate to 30 mL/h.
Dispense droplets of the alginate-bacteria solution into the stirred CaCl2 solution.
Harden the spherical beads for 1 h in the 0.25 M CaCl2 solution.
Discard the CaCl2 and wash the beads twice by swirling the beads carefully in 50 mL sterile 0.9% saline solution in a beaker.
Transfer 20 beads to 50 mL prewarmed LB medium in a 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask.
Incubate at 37°C and 100 rpm for 24 h.
Transfer beads to a new beaker and rinse them gently by swirling in 50 mL 0.9% sterile NaCl for <1 min to remove non-embedded bacteria.
Place a single bead into a plastic insert (calWell™, Symcel AB).
Position plastic inserts into titanium vials of the calPlate™ (Symcel AB, Sweden).

Add 190 μL fresh LB medium supplemented with 0.2% L-arabinose resulting in 200 μL total volume in each well.
Note: Handle the filled inserts carefully to avoid spilling. It is advised to use sterile tweezers for insert handling to prevent contamination. Liquid on the rim of the vial can interfere with the signal (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A).
The calScreener biocalorimetry procedure
Timing: 1–2 days (or longer)
In this step, we set up the calPlate™ with the sample-containing plastic inserts and perform live cell metabolic measurements. Isothermal calorimetry with the calScreener™ allows evaluation of overall metabolic activity of a sample by continuous measuring of heat flow (HF, μW). Samples are prepared prior to insertion and measurement, which can be done for unlimited time, typically 24 h for fast growing cells.
We have optimized planktonic culture and a surface attached biofilm model for instrument specific plastic inserts, including cell number and pre-incubation times.
Setup calPlate™ for measurement
Timing: 1–2 days (or longer)
Setup the calPlate™ (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]) and insert into the calScreener™ for automatic and continuous measurement of released heat. Vials at positions A 1–8 and F 1–8 serve as thermodynamic references and contain sterile medium, that is used for the sampled. Culture and medium controls shall be added separately to vials at sample positions (B1–E8).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2661-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Schematic setup of the calPlate™
(A) After sample preparation, (A) transfer samples in plastic inserts into titanium vials that are placed in the 48 well plastic holder.
(B) Place the lids on the titanium vials and close them with the help of a torque wrench.
Place 48 sterile titanium vials into the metal holder of the calPlate™ on the sample station.
Place plastic inserts to vials in reference positions (A 1–8 and F 1–8).

Fill reference vials with equal volume and media as used for the sample vials, here 200 μL LB medium.
Note: Use gloves and/or sterile tweezers to minimize the risk of contamination.
For biofilm and alginate bead samples, transfer the plastic inserts containing the samples in the titanium vials on the plate.
For planktonic cultures, place empty plastic inserts into titanium vials on the calPlate™ and subsequently add 200 μL aliquots of diluted samples to the vials.
Place the lids loosely on the vials (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Tighten the lids using the torque wrench set on 40 cNm force.
Measure metabolic activity of the samples
Prepare the system for measurement.
Check the temperature setting on the temperature control unit; it should be set at 37°C.
Open calView™ software and start new experiment (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2661-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. How to start a new measurement
(A and B) In calView (A) create a new experiment and (B) start data collection prior to plate insertion.
Stepwise insertion of the calPlate™ with temperature equilibration steps (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2661-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Plate handling
(A) Place the calPlate in the correct orientation on the bridge.
(B) Stepwise insertion, via position 1 (10 min) and position 2 (20 min), of the plate to allow temperature equilibration to instrument temperature, here 37°C.
(C) Retract the plate handling arm with the magnets pulled in during measurement.
(D) Retrieve the plate with help of the magnets of the plate handling arm.
Retract the plate insertion arm from the calScreener™.
Place the calPlate™ on the bridge (column 8 facing insertion opening).
Gently push the calPlate™ on position one using the plate insertion arm and let the system stabilize for 10 min.
Optional: annotate sample content in software for individual vials.

Push plate insertion arm to position two and wait for 20 min for temperature equilibration of the system.
Push plate to final position 3 (measuring position) and activate Reaction Start in calView™.
Retract plate insertion arm to Start position (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).
Run experiment for desired time (e.g., 24 h).
Note: Check that the plate is correctly placed on the heat sensor. Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5] (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7])
Critical: Make sure you do not move the plate from the sensor when retracting the arm.
Remove calPlate™.
Press Stop in calView™ to end the experiment and save the file for further analysis.
Insert the plate insertion arm completely and retrieve the calPlateTM with help of the magnets (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D).
Open the lids using the torque and retrieve the sample for further analysis if required, otherwise discard.
Validate data quality
Timing: 1 h
Check and validate quality of measurement and prepare data for analysis.
Open the experiment file in calView™.
Normalize data with baseline correction (select approx. 20 min in lag phase with signal between 0–10 μW).
Export ∗csv file (for analysis in calData, GraphPad, Microsoft Excel or any other compatible software solution).
Check data quality and see if there were any issues with the measurement; see troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3], troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7], troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9] and troubleshooting 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.11].

Figure 5. Metabolic parameters that can be analyzed with the help of calData
Examples are time to the first signal maximum (Time to peak), time to signal detection, maximum metabolic activity (μW) and total metabolic activity (J). These parameters can be compared across different samples.
Optional: For tailored metabolic parameter analysis upload data to webtool calData. https://symcel.com/analysis-tools/calorimetric-growth/[href=https://symcel.com/analysis-tools/calorimetric-growth/] (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
